WINTER IN TOLEDO: December 1432 - Mid-March 1433

The months that follow become a gift—the kind of peaceful, productive time that kings rarely experience.

Isabel and the Second Pregnancy

By late December, Isabel's suspicions are confirmed. The royal physician examines her and pronounces what both of you already knew in your hearts: she is expecting again, likely due in late August or early September. But unlike the first pregnancy, this one begins gently. No severe sickness, no debilitating fatigue. Isabel blooms.

"I think," she tells you one January evening as snow falls outside the windows, "that God is being merciful this time. Or perhaps it's just that I'm not so afraid." She rests her hand on her still-flat stomach. "I know what to expect now. I know you'll be here. That makes all the difference."

The physicians are cautiously optimistic. They monitor her closely given the trauma of Catalina's birth, but the pregnancy progresses normally through the winter months. Isabel maintains her strength, walks daily through the palace gardens when weather permits, and glows with that particular radiance that comes from joy rather than just biology.

By March, when your departure for Granada approaches, she is five months along—visibly pregnant but healthy and strong. "Go," she tells you firmly. "Do what you must in Granada and Rome. But be back by August. That's all I ask."

Catalina's Development

Your daughter transforms during these months. At ten months when you returned from Granada, she was just beginning to crawl and babble. By mid-March, at fourteen months, she walks—unsteadily, arms outstretched for balance, but she walks. She toddles from you to Isabel, squealing with delight when you catch her.

And then, one February morning at breakfast, it happens. Catalina is in your lap, reaching for a piece of bread. She looks up at you and says clearly: "Papa."

You freeze. Isabel gasps from across the table. Catalina, oblivious to the magnitude of the moment, simply smiles and says it again: "Papa."

"Did you hear that?" Isabel's eyes fill with tears. "Her first word!"

The next week brings "Mama," and within days Catalina is attempting to name everything she sees—"pan" for bread, "agua" for water, simplified versions of the Portuguese and Castilian words she hears daily. You find yourself spending hours simply talking to her, watching her try to repeat sounds, delighting in her growing personality.

She has Isabel's eyes but your determination—when she wants something, she pursues it relentlessly, crawling or toddling after it with single-minded focus. She adores music, clapping her hands when musicians play in the hall. And she has developed the endearing habit of falling asleep on your chest in the evenings, her small hand clutching your thumb.

"She won't remember these months," Isabel says softly one night as you both watch Catalina sleep. "But we will. When you're old and gray, you'll remember her first words, her first steps. That you were here for them."

The Mendoza Council's Triumph

Don Íñigo López de Mendoza presents the Council of Great Houses' progress in early January, and the results exceed even your optimistic expectations.

"Your Majesty," he reports with barely concealed pride, "we have conducted comprehensive audits on the three initial member families—my own House Mendoza, House Enríquez, and House de la Cerda. The results are... illuminating."

The Council has identified an additional 15,000 maravedís in underpayments from just these three houses—not malicious tax evasion, but the accumulated result of outdated assessments, optimistic valuations, and convenient accounting errors. All three families have paid immediately and without protest.

"But that's not the remarkable part," Don Íñigo continues. "The remarkable part is what happened next."

Word of the Council's success has spread through the nobility like wildfire. By February, three more great houses—House Velasco, House Manrique, and House Álvarez de Toledo—have formally petitioned to join the Council. They want to be part of this voluntary accountability system, to be recognized as great families who police themselves rather than wait for Crown Marshals to arrive with ultimatums.

"They see it as a privilege now," Don Íñigo explains. "A mark of distinction. Being part of the Council means you're one of the families that sets the standard, not one that merely follows it. And the peer pressure..." He smiles. "No great house wants to be the one that disappoints the others. The shame of being audited and found wanting by your peers is worse than any royal fine."

By March, the Council has grown to six member houses and is discussing formal procedures, regular meeting schedules, and standardized audit practices. Don Íñigo suggests that in another year, the Council could be handling most noble tax compliance without Crown Marshal involvement at all.

"This is what sustainable governance looks like," Álvaro observes after the meeting. "Not the king forcing compliance through threat of force, but the nobility choosing to govern themselves because it serves their honor and interests. Don Íñigo has created something that could outlast all of us."

Trade Delegation Success

Diego de Daza spends January and February organizing the trade delegation to Italy with meticulous care. He selects six experienced merchants—two from Seville, two from Toledo, one from Burgos, one from Córdoba—along with two royal officials to represent crown interests and one translator fluent in Italian dialects.

Their instructions are clear: negotiate favorable terms for Málaga and other captured ports, establish relationships with major Italian trading houses, and secure agreements for regular commerce. They are authorized to offer competitive customs rates, guaranteed property rights, and access to African trade routes through Granada.

The delegation departs in late February for Genoa and Venice. By early March, first letters arrive reporting remarkable success. The Genoese, who already have relationships with Castile from the Granada campaign, are eager to formalize commercial arrangements. They see Málaga as a perfect complement to their existing Mediterranean network and are willing to commit to regular shipping routes.

Venice is more cautious but intrigued. Their merchants want to see the port infrastructure before making commitments, but they acknowledge that a western Mediterranean route through Málaga could save them weeks of travel time for goods destined for Atlantic markets.

Most surprisingly, both cities express interest in the African trade potential. The idea of a secure western route for gold, ivory, and spices—avoiding the Ottoman-dominated eastern Mediterranean—appeals to merchants who have watched Turkish power expand with alarm.

Diego reports that the delegation has also made contact with Florentine banking houses interested in financing Castilian commercial ventures. "They see a kingdom with growing naval power, secure ports, and royal backing," his letter notes. "They want to invest before others recognize the opportunity."

Military Academy Excellence

Sir Thomas Beaumont's Royal Military Academy produces its first results by March, and they are impressive.

The Academy has trained twenty-three junior officers over the winter—younger sons of noble families, promoted sergeants, a few foreign volunteers including two Germans and a Pole. The curriculum combines theoretical study (tactics, logistics, fortification design) with practical training (drill, command exercises, siege simulations).

You visit the Academy in February to observe training exercises. What you see is revelation. The officers aren't just memorizing maneuvers—they're thinking tactically, adapting to changing situations, coordinating multiple units with precision that would have been impossible a year ago.

Sir Thomas demonstrates with obvious pride. "Watch this, Your Majesty." He sets up a scenario: defending a fortress against superior numbers. The young officers split into defending and attacking teams. Within minutes, they're deploying counter-battery positions, organizing sorties, calculating supply requirements, adjusting to simulated intelligence reports.

"This is what I learned fighting in France," Sir Thomas explains. "The English win battles not because we're braver, but because our officers understand warfare as a system—supply, intelligence, terrain, morale, all of it. These men are learning that."

By March, five of the graduating officers receive immediate commissions in the royal forces. Two are assigned to garrison commands in Granada. One joins the artillery train under Master Gunner Pietro Calabrese. Two more are retained as Academy instructors for the next cohort.

"Give me three more years," Sir Thomas tells you, "and we'll have fifty officers who understand modern warfare better than anyone in Christendom except perhaps the Ottomans. And in five years? We'll surpass even them."

International Developments

Letters from abroad bring consistently positive news throughout the winter.

From Basel (Fray Hernando, January): The Castilian delegation continues to wield unexpected influence. Two more church reform proposals citing "Castilian practice" have been incorporated into Council decrees. The Hussite negotiations are progressing—slowly, but progressing. Three of the contentious Articles have been partially resolved through compromise language that both Bohemians and Rome can accept.

Most remarkably, Fray Hernando reports that Cardinal Cesarini has begun consulting him not just on theological matters but on practical governance questions. "He asks how Your Majesty maintains both papal loyalty and reform commitment," the letter notes. "How you strengthen royal authority while respecting noble rights. Your example is teaching more than theology here—it's teaching statecraft."

From Basel (Fray Hernando, February): Cardinal Cesarini writes a personal letter—addressed directly to you, not just transmitted through Fray Hernando. In it, he explicitly praises Castile's Basel influence:

"Your Majesty, your kingdom's delegation has become the conscience of this Council. When extremes clash, it is the Castilian voice that calls both sides back to reason. When theory departs from practice, it is Castilian experience that grounds us. I write not as papal legate but as a churchman grateful for your witness. The crusade you fought in Granada continues here in Basel, though the weapons are words rather than swords."

From Portugal (King João I, February): Isabel's father sends a warm letter confirming his attendance at the Granada Te Deum. He is bringing his eldest son Prince Duarte and his younger son Prince Henrique (Henry the Navigator). The letter expresses genuine joy at the Reconquista's completion and mentions that "matters of mutual interest regarding our southern neighbors" should be discussed when you meet—a clear reference to Morocco and North African strategy.

"My daughter writes that you are to be a father again," King João adds. "God grant you a son this time, though I confess my granddaughter Catalina holds my heart regardless. May this pregnancy bring joy rather than the fear of the first."

From Hungary (János Hunyadi, March): A second letter arrives from the Transylvanian voivode. He has been consulting with King Władysław III of Poland about potential anti-Ottoman coordination. "Poland is interested," Hunyadi writes, "especially if Castile—a kingdom that actually completes what it starts—leads the alliance. They've heard too many promises from German princes who talk of crusading but never march. Your reputation changes calculations."

Shipyard Reports

Perhaps most tangibly exciting are the regular reports from the Cantabrian shipyards where your fleet is under construction.

In January, the keels for all nine ships have been laid—five war galleys and four carracks. Master shipwright Gonzalo Fernández sends detailed progress sketches showing the frame construction. Everything is on schedule.

By February, the galleys' frames are taking shape. The carracks—larger and more complex—are progressing more slowly, but still within projected timelines. Gonzalo reports he has secured excellent Basque oak for the hulls and has hired additional master craftsmen to ensure quality.

In March comes unexpected good news: the flagship construction is ahead of schedule. Gonzalo believes it might be ready by July rather than August, which would allow it to sail you to Rome instead of requiring overland travel. "It would be fitting," Gonzalo writes, "for Your Majesty to arrive at the Vatican aboard a Castilian flagship flying the royal standard. Let them see that Spain is a naval power now."

The image appeals to you—sailing into Rome's port of Ostia with the True Cross and Santiago's bone aboard a Castilian warship, cannon mounted on the rails, royal banner streaming. A symbol of the kingdom you're building.

Family Christmas

The Christmas season becomes a particular joy. You celebrate Christ's birth with Isabel, Catalina, and the court in Toledo's great cathedral. Catalina is fascinated by the nativity scene, reaching out to touch the wooden figures of Mary, Joseph, and the infant Jesus.

On Christmas Eve, as snow falls gently outside, you hold a small private celebration in your chambers. Isabel is four months pregnant but energetic. Catalina toddles around excitedly, delighted by the festive decorations and the musicians playing carols.

"This," Isabel says softly as you sit together by the fire, Catalina drowsing in her lap, "is what I dreamed marriage could be. Not just duty and alliance, but... this. Joy. Family. Love."

You pull her close. "Two years ago, I was eighteen and terrified of everything except God's will. Now I'm twenty, and I've learned that God's will includes moments like this."

"Do you ever think," Isabel asks, "about how unlikely all of this was? That the shy Portuguese princess and the crusader king would find this?" She touches your face. "I thank God for you every day, Juan. For your patience, your kindness, your..." She smiles. "Your faith, even when you're uncertain. Especially then."

March Departure Approaching

By mid-March, with spring arriving and travel becoming feasible again, you begin preparations for departure to Granada. The bags are packed. The escort is assembled—your royal guard, the crusader banner contingent, various officials who will help prepare for the Te Deum ceremony.

Isabel is five months pregnant and showing clearly now. The physicians are pleased with her progress. "If all continues this well," the senior physician tells you privately, "this birth should be far less traumatic than the first. The body remembers how, and she is healthier and less fearful this time."

Your final days in Toledo are bittersweet. You spend every possible hour with Isabel and Catalina. Your daughter has started saying "Papa go?" whenever she sees bags being packed, and it breaks your heart a little each time.

"Two months in Granada preparing and hosting the Te Deum," you remind Isabel. "Then two months traveling to Rome and Basel. I'll be back by late July, early August at the latest. Well before the baby comes."

"I trust you," Isabel says simply. "And I trust God. Go build your kingdom, Juan. We'll be here when you return. And this time..." She places your hand on her pregnant belly. "This time, you'll come home to meet your second child, not leave right after the birth."

On the morning of your departure—March 18, 1433—you hold Catalina one more time. She's crying, not understanding why Papa is leaving. "Papa back soon," you promise her in simplified words she can understand. "Papa loves you."

You kiss Isabel goodbye, holding her longer than protocol requires. "Stay healthy," you whisper. "Both of you."

"We will," she promises. "Go with God, my love."

As you ride south from Toledo toward Granada, you carry with you the memory of four months of peace, joy, and family that sustain you for the journey ahead. Isabel is healthy and pregnant. Catalina is thriving and speaking her first words. Your kingdom is prospering. The nobility is governing itself. Your institutions are working. Your international reputation is growing.

For the first time since taking the throne three years ago, you feel not just like a king doing his duty, but like a man building something that will endure.

The evening before your departure, you meet privately with Álvaro in your study. Maps and documents cover the table—the accumulated work of governing Castile that will now fall entirely to him in your absence.

"Four months," Álvaro says, reviewing the timeline. "Granada through April for the Te Deum. Rome in May. Basel in June and early July. Back by late July or early August." He meets your eyes. Catalina looks up and sees you. "Papa!" She toddles over with her arms outstretched, and you sweep her up. She's gotten heavier in these four months—no longer an infant but a little girl.

Isabel comes to stand beside you, and for a long moment, the three of you are simply together—your family, whole and safe for these last hours before you leave.

The Morning of Departure - March 18, 1433

Dawn breaks cold and clear over Toledo. Your escort is assembled in the main courtyard—Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles with the royal guard, fifty crusaders carrying the banner, various officials and servants for the journey. The horses stamp and snort in the morning chill, their breath steaming.

You're mounted on your warhorse, wearing traveling clothes and your commander's clasp. The True Cross fragment and Santiago's bone rest in their reliquaries, carefully packed for the journey to Granada and eventually Rome.

Isabel stands on the steps with Catalina in her arms. Your wife is wrapped in a heavy cloak against the cold, her pregnancy visible beneath it. She's not crying—she promised herself she wouldn't—but her eyes are bright.

Catalina is crying, though. She's reaching for you, not understanding why Papa is on the tall horse instead of holding her. "Papa! Papa!" Her little voice breaks your heart.

Isabel holds her tighter and raises one hand in farewell. Around the courtyard, servants and courtiers have gathered to see their king depart. Álvaro stands beside Isabel—your constable, your advisor, your friend who will protect your family while you're gone.

The captain of the guard looks to you, awaiting the order to move out.

Late March - Early April, 1433

Granada transforms over the coming weeks into something Iberia has not seen in living memory—a gathering place for all the Christian monarchs of the peninsula. The Alhambra, which three months ago housed a Muslim Sultan, now prepares to receive Portuguese princes, Aragonese royalty, and the redeemed Infantes who once rebelled against your rule.

The Portuguese Arrival - March 30, 1433

King João I of Portugal arrives first, and his entrance is magnificent. At seventy-three, he is still vigorous, riding at the head of a column that includes his eldest son Prince Duarte (heir to Portugal) and his younger son Prince Henrique—Henry the Navigator, already famous for his interest in exploration and African ventures.

You meet them at Granada's gates with full ceremony. João dismounts stiffly but with dignity, and when he embraces you, there's genuine warmth.

Prince Duarte, a serious man in his early forties, bows respectfully. "Your Majesty, Portugal rejoices in Castile's triumph. The Reconquista's completion is victory for all Christendom."

But it's Prince Henrique who surprises you. Younger, perhaps thirty-eight, with an intense, thoughtful gaze. "Your Majesty," he says, "I've heard of your plans for Mediterranean commerce, your fleet construction. I would very much like to discuss these matters while we're here. Portugal's experience with African coasts and Atlantic navigation might prove... complementary to your own endeavors."

That evening, at a private dinner in the Alhambra, João raises the Gibraltar Strait question you'd hoped to discuss. "Juan, my scouts report you control Gibraltar now. And I, as you know, hold Ceuta." He smiles knowingly. "Two kingdoms, two sides of the strait. Shall we compete, or shall we cooperate?"

The conversation that follows is productive. João is intrigued by your joint patrol proposal, the shared intelligence, the coordinated approach to Moroccan relations. "Better to work together than waste energy in rivalry," he concludes. "Portugal and Castile united could control all traffic between Mediterranean and Atlantic. That's power, Juan. Real power."

The Navarrese Arrival - April 1, 1433

Infante Juan de Aragón—now properly styled as Juan II, King of Navarre—arrives next, and his entrance is more complicated emotionally. The man who once rebelled against you, who seized Arévalo while you journeyed to Rome, now rides into the city you conquered as your honored guest.

He brings his nine-year-old son Carlos, Prince of Viana—the boy whose inheritance rights you swore to protect in exchange for his father's renunciation of all claims to Aragón's throne.

When Juan of Navarre kneels before you in formal greeting, you raise him up immediately and embrace him. "Brother crusader," you say simply. "Welcome to Granada."

His eyes glisten. "Your Majesty, I... when I took the oath before the True Cross, I didn't fully comprehend what I was becoming. Young Carlos watches this exchange with wide eyes. The boy is well-mannered, intelligent-looking. When you speak to him, asking about his studies and his kingdom of Navarre, he answers thoughtfully.

That evening, Juan of Navarre makes a request. "Your Majesty, when the Te Deum is celebrated, might I be permitted to carry one of the sacred relics in the procession? The Second Infante - April 2, 1433

Infante Enrique de Aragón arrives the following day, alone and simply dressed. Unlike his brother Juan who retained a kingdom, Enrique renounced everything and has lived these past years as essentially a landless noble who earned redemption through crusade service.

You showed me what true kingship looks like. What faith looks like." He pulls back. "The lands in Granada you promised—I don't need them, Your Majesty. If you have use for me, I'll serve.
